questions.question: First indication that a well is flowing?
questions.explanation: Increased flow rate is the earliest positive indicator—formation fluid entering displaces mud out. All other signs come later or indicate different conditions.

questions.question: Action at drilling break?
questions.explanation: Drilling break = ROP increase = possible new formation. Stop and flow check before proceeding. Don't assume kick (shut in) or ignore it (continue).

questions.question: Positive kick indicators? (SELECT TWO)
questions.explanation: Kick = formation fluid entering = MORE flow out (A) and MORE volume in pits (D). Decreases indicate opposite—losses, not kicks.

questions.question: What makes pit gain detection difficult?
questions.explanation: Shaker overflow bypasses pit level monitoring—mud goes overboard, not to pits. Can't detect gain if mud doesn't reach measurement point.

questions.question: Action upon observing positive kick indicator?
questions.explanation: POSITIVE indicator = kick confirmed. Shut in immediately. Flow check is for warnings or drilling breaks, not confirmed kicks.

questions.question: 15 stands pulled dry, 8.2 bbl fluid used, no flow. Action?

options.B: Trip back; monitor displaced volume; circulate bottoms up
options.D: Pump high density fluid into annulus

questions.explanation: 8.2 bbl for 15 stands seems low—potential swab without obvious flow yet. Run back to restore hydrostatic and circulate to verify wellbore condition. Don't risk continuing.
